## What can go wrong?

* Bad model.
--

* Quantitative extrapolation.
--

* Qualitative extrapolation. 
--

* Overconfidence due to overfitting.
--

* Black swans. 

---

## Bad Model


```{r, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
set.seed(1)
library(tidyverse)
d <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(100, 0, 1.5),
  y = x + x^2 + rnorm(100)
)

ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x) + 
  geom_point()
```

---

## Quantitative extrapolation

```{r, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
set.seed(1)
library(tidyverse)
d <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(100, 0, 1.5),
  y = x + x^2 + rnorm(100)
)

ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x + I(x^2)) + 
  geom_point()
```

---

## Quantitative extrapolation


```{r, echo = FALSE}
lm(y ~ x + I(x^2), data = d) %>%
  broom::tidy() %>%
  knitr::kable()
```

--

.question[
What would the predicted value be when x = 10?
]

--

```{r}
x0 <- c(1, 10, 10^2)
beta_hat <- c(0.056, 1.01, 0.95)
t(x0) %*% beta_hat
```


---

## Quantitative extrapolation

```{r, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x + I(x^2)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_point(aes(x = 10, y = 105.156), color = "red", shape = "star")
```

## Overconfidence due to overfitting

```{r, echo = FALSE}
set.seed(1)
d <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(100),
  y = x + rnorm(100)
)
ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ poly(x, 10), se = FALSE) +
  geom_point()
```

---

## Black Swan events

* Sometimes errors can appear to be normally distributed because you havenâ€™t seen enough data to be aware of extremes

* This is of particular concern in **financial applications** where stock prices are characterized by mostly small changes (normally distributed) but with infrequent large changes
